instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.DDREG_EN: What is DDREG_EN? This is a typo of DDRREG_EN When you see DDREG_EN, assume they meant to type DDRREG_EN.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Hello.
The laptop turns on, but there is no chime and image.

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
1 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_VTTSNS</SIGNAL> - [B]0[/B]
2 - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.2
3 - <SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> — [B]0[/B]
4 - GND
5 - <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S3_DDR_BUF</SIGNAL> — [B]0[/B]
6 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_1V8_VREF</SIGNAL> - 1.8
7 - <SIGNAL>GND_DDREG_SGND</SIGNAL>
8 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_FB</SIGNAL> - 1.2
9 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_VDDQSNS</SIGNAL> — 1.2
10 - GND
11 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_DRVL</SIGNAL> - [B]0[/B]
12 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5.05
13 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_LL</SIGNAL> - 1.2
14 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_DRVH</SIGNAL> - 1.2
15 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_VBST</SIGNAL> - 6.2            
16 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.31
17 - [B]<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.31[/B]
18 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_TRIP</SIGNAL> - [B]0-[/B]
19 - <SIGNAL>DDREG_MODE</SIGNAL> — [B]0 [/B]
20 - [B]<SIGNAL>DDREG_PGOOD</SIGNAL> — 3.3  [/B][I]if present, do you need to worry about <SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> [/I][B]?[/B]

also missing
<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> — 0
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> — 0
<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> — 0

replaced <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>, nothing has changed!
There is no short circuit on the board!

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 1,8
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - 1,5
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 1,2
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 1,05
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1,05
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_HSIO</SIGNAL> - 1,05
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> — 1,8
All powerGoods are present!
USB lights up!

thanks

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Any history fault available?
Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>?
Also check <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Thx)
the motherboard  is clean!
The only thing that I noticed strange is that with a 45W power supply the board starts up, and with 85W it detects but does not start, is this normal?

             
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> — 3,4
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>— 3,4
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 1
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> — 3,3

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
85W charger can trigger VD0R sensor (overvoltage).
It should start in SMC bypass mode however.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
when the battery is connected with the adapter 85 starts. Bypassing  smс also starts but without changes
and please tell me how to find VD0R sensor
Thx

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
"how to find VD0R sensor"
Did you search in pdf?
Look at page 42, just in case.

"how to bypass smс"
So many times explained on the forum...
Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressed 5-10s; it should start with fan spinning at max.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Yes, I'm sorry, I found everything and did it! the message above was fixed. 
Bypassing smс  wish 85W also starts but without changes, no chime no image

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
When you say "USB lights up!" you mean activity LED of USB drive blinks?

<SIGNAL>PPVTT_S3_DDR_BUF</SIGNAL> should be 0.6V, without it <SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> will stay at 0V instead of 0.6V.
Measure exact resistance to ground on both lines and make sure <CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7462</CAPACITOR> look good.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
I have a USB for tests, when I connect it, it lights up and shows that 5V is coming to it.
Everything looks fine
<CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR>- 2,6MOm
<CAPACITOR>C7462</CAPACITOR> -0,8KOm

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
No RAM activity, if missing  <SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> .
Steady light on USB doesn't help.
You must test with a device which has Link LED, to confirm USB activity.

Try known good BIOS file.

threads.message:

Maybe you have some other ideas that i can check?

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground at <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, pins 1, 3, 5.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
On all these legs, a strange value of 596.5, I don't know what it is, but it's not 0 like in other cases.
It still does not give 0.6V.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, pins 1, 3, 5 there are no short circuits on these lines (infinity).

On all these legs, a strange value of 596.5, I don't know what it is, but it's not 0 like in other cases.
It still does not give 0.6V.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Impossible to get infinite (OL) reading measuring diode mode correctly!
Remeber, ALWAYS red probe at ground in diode mode.

Be aware, we not always search for pure short...

threads.message:
Thanks for the tip.
1 and 3 = 0.2, 5 = 1.02
I also checked the resistance: 1 and 3 = 0.8. 5 = 2.7

threads.message:

Thx

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Is not BIOS then.
It should boot with working dump, even no clean ME.
BTW, we have posted links for clean BIOS on the forum, just search.

Probably bad CPU, in this case...

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Yes, I took the BIOS from this forum (but I also put 2 bios from donors). can you advise  [SIZE=4][B]Post Card Testeur[/B][/SIZE] for macbook?
Removed 7462 and 7450 (0.6v appeared on it). replaced , i put it in its place <CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> and 0.6 disappears!!!!
thx

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message: can i remove the 7462 and 7450  and connect them with a wire from one to the other? I don't know if there is a need if they do not touch GND?

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Do not mix <CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR>/62, very different capacity.
Be sure all traces and solders are good there.

Do not tie together VTT and VTTREF.
Do you get high level at pin 17/<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>?

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Ok, thx
I just removed did not connect (<CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> / 62), now on <CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> 0.6v!
pin 17/<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> = 3.2v
maybe i need to press the chip when soldering (for xw7400)?

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Be sure to put 0.22uF on V7450.
If you place higher value there, can block the reference power supply.
I hope both XW7400/60 bridges are good.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Ok
I replaced the donor <CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> with the same one (0.22uF)!
(<CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> / 62) = but were good.
I can't find the XW7400 / 60 and how can I check them?

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message: Check continuity between the components where these bridges appear in schematic.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message: if you keep in mind that there must be a signal between these lines, it is!

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
About <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>:
VTTREF must be present at pin 5, when pin 16 is high.
Once pin 17 goes high, you should get 0.6V at pins 1 & 3.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
pin 16 have 3.3
when I put <CAPACITOR>C7450</CAPACITOR> in place, 0.6 disappears!
I removed the <CAPACITOR>C7415</CAPACITOR>, which is not a good idea, but I saw that pin 6 became 2.5 instead of 1.8 and 0.8 appeared on pin 3.
I replaced the <CAPACITOR>C7415</CAPACITOR> but the situation has not changed.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> again.
Be sure to get good solders and traces are OK.

threads.title: Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 no chime, no image (<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>)
threads.message: I noticed that constant cyclic reboots from the battery. I thought that by deleting 7462 I disabled the connection to the cpu but you are probably right, this is CPU
